en_first_half: "We'll take care of her, Laila jan," one of the women said with an air of self-importance. Laila had been to funerals before where she had
en_second_half: seen women like this, women who relished all things that had to do with death, official consolers who let no one trespass on their self-appointed duties.
en_Completion: seen women like this one, women who made it a point to let it be known that they were the ones in charge, the ones who would look after everything. Laila had always found it both admirable and annoying. She had always wondered if these women were truly selfless or just self-important. But now, as she looked at this woman, she felt a sense of gratitude. She knew that she could trust her to take care of her mother.

"With all the time I've spent in Peshawar, I've become pretty proficient in Urdu. Anyway, what I gathered was that your friend was in a lorry full of refugees, twenty-three of
en_second_half: them, all headed for Peshawar. Near the border, they were caught in cross fire. A rocket hit the lorry. Probably a stray, but you never know with these people, you never know. There were only six survivors, all of them admitted to the same unit. Three died within twenty-four hours. Two of them lived-sisters, as I understood it-and had been discharged.
en_Completion: them, all headed for Peshawar. Now, I don't know what exactly happened, but somehow the lorry skidded off the road and crashed. Your friend was the only survivor. He was badly hurt, but he managed to crawl out of the wreckage and make his way to a nearby village. The villagers took him in and nursed him back to health. That's where I met him, in that village. He was still recovering from his injuries,

es_first_half: –Una de las enfermeras me contó lo que le había ocurrido -prosiguió Abdul Sharif al tiempo que se daba golpes en el pecho con el puño, como tratando de facilitar el paso de la pastilla-. Con la de veces que he estado en Peshawar, he aprendido bastante bien el urdu. El caso es que me contó que tu amigo se encontraba en un camión lleno de refugiados, veintitrés exactamente, que se

Allí el futuro carecía de importancia y el pasado sólo contenía una lección: que el amor era un error dañino, y su cómplice, la esperanza, una ilusión traicionera. Y siempre que esas dos venenosas flores gemelas empezaban a brotar en la cuarteada tierra de su campo, Mariam las arrancaba de raíz. Las arrancaba y las aniquilaba antes de que pudieran crecer.

en_first_half: He made a vow to himself, Tariq said, after his mother's illness, that they would not spend another winter in camp. He'd work, save, move them to an apartment in Peshawar with heating and clean water. When spring came, he looked for work. From time to time, a truck
en_second_half: came to camp early in the morning and rounded up a couple of dozen boys, took them to a field to move stones or an orchard to pick apples in exchange for a little money, sometimes a blanket, a pair of shoes. But they never wanted him, Tariq said.
en_Completion: would rumble into the camp, spewing exhaust and kicking up clouds of dust, and Tariq would rush to join the throng of men and boys who swarmed around it, hoping to find work as laborers or porters. He'd climb up onto the truck bed, his eyes scanning the crowded space for a spot to claim, and begin to haul crates and bundles, his muscles straining with the effort. The work was backbreaking, but it paid,
vi_first_half: Tariq nói rằng sau trận ốm đó của mẹ, anh đã thề với mình rằng họ sẽ không phải trải qua bất cứ mùa đông nào ở trại tị nạn nữa. Anh sẽ đi làm, để dành tiền và chuyển mẹ đến một căn hộ ở Peshawar với nguồn nước nóng sạch. Khi mùa xuân đến, anh bắt đầu tìm việc.
vi_second_half: Mỗi ngày, một chiếc xe tải đến khu trại từ sáng sớm và lấy khoảng vài chục thanh thiếu niên, đưa họ đến công trường để chuyển đá hay đến các vườn cây ăn quả để thu hoạch táo, công là ít tiền lẻ, đôi khi là cái chăn, đôi giày. Nhưng họ không bao giờ muốn nhận anh, Tariq kể.
vi_Completion: Trong những ngày đầu tiên, anh đã đi bộ hàng chục cây số đến các nhà máy và công ty, nhưng không ai muốn thuê một cậu bé tị nạn mười lăm tuổi. Sau đó, anh quyết định đến chợ để tìm việc làm. Anh đã gặp một người đàn ông đang bán trái cây và rau quả, và anh đã đề nghị giúp đỡ ông ta. Người đàn ông đã đồng ý, và Tariq đã bắt đầu làm việc cho
es_first_half: Después de la enfermedad de su madre, continuó Tariq, se juró a sí mismo que no pasarían otro invierno en el campamento. Trabajaría y ahorraría dinero para instalarse en Peshawar, en un apartamento con calefacción y agua corriente. Y, en efecto, cuando llegó la primavera buscó trabajo. De vez en cuando, llegaba un
es_second_half: camión al campamento por la mañana temprano y se llevaba a un par de docenas de chicos a un campo a quitar piedras, o a un huerto a recoger manzanas, a cambio de algo de dinero, o a veces una manta o un par de zapatos. Pero a él nunca lo querían, dijo Tariq.
es_Completion: camión al campamento y se llevaba a algunos de los hombres a trabajar en la construcción de una carretera en las montañas. Tariq se subió a uno de esos camiones y se fue a trabajar. Durante todo el verano, trabajó en la carretera, y cuando llegó el invierno, había ahorrado lo suficiente para instalarse en Peshawar con su familia. Alquiló un
tr_first_half: Annesinin hastalığından sonra, kendine bir söz vermiş, kampta bir kış daha geçirmemeye yemin etmişti. Çalışacak, para biriktirecek, annesini Peşaver’de temiz suyu, sobası olan bir daireye taşıyacaktı. Bahar gelince, iş aramaya koyuldu. Arada bir, bir

en_first_half: "I know you're a married woman and a mother now. And here I am, after all these years, after all that's happened, showing up at your
en_second_half: doorstep. Probably, it isn't proper, or fair, but I've come such a long way to see you, and… Oh, Laila, I wish I'd never left you."
en_Completion: doorstep, uninvited and unannounced, like a ghost from the past. I know I shouldn't be here, but I couldn't help myself. I had to see you, to know that you're okay, to know that life has been kind to you."

en_first_half: None of the women in Mariam's cell were serving time for violent crime-they were all there for the common offense of "running away from home." As a result, Mariam gained some
en_second_half: notoriety among them, became a kind of celebrity. The women eyed her with a reverent, almost awestruck, expression. They offered her their blankets. They competed to share their food with her.
en_Completion: insight into the desperate measures Afghan women would take to escape their circumstances. Mariam heard tales of forced marriages, domestic violence, and families who treated their daughters as servants. The stories were heartbreaking, and Mariam realized that she was not alone in her struggles. Despite the harsh conditions of the prison, Mariam found solace in the companionship of her fellow inmates. They shared what little food they had, and Mariam learned how to make a thin soup with a few

en_first_half: "My father, may he rest in peace, was so very fond of her," he says at last. "He was the one who sangazan in her ear when she was born, you know. He visited her every
en_second_half: week, never missed. Sometimes he took me with him. He was her tutor, yes, but he was a friend too. He was a charitable man, my father. It nearly broke him when Jalil Khan gave her away."
en_Completion: day, and brought her gifts, and told her stories of the old country. He was so proud of her, and she was so fond of him. I remember how she would sit on his lap and listen to his stories, her eyes wide with wonder. He was a kind and gentle man, and he loved her with all his heart."
vi_first_half: “Bố của tôi, cầu cho ông được yên nghỉ, đã rất yêu quý bà ấy,” cuối cùng ông nói. “Ông chính là người đã hát azan vào tai bà ấy khi bà ấy mới sinh ra, cô ạ. Ông đến thăm bà ấy hằng tuần, không bao giờ lỡ
vi_second_half: cả. Đôi lần ông đưa tôi cùng đi với ông. Ông là một người giảng kinh, đúng thế, nhưng ông cũng là một người bạn nữa. Ông ấy, bố tôi, là một người đàn ông nhân từ. Ông gần như suy sụp khi Jalil Khan gả bà ấy đi.”
vi_Completion: hẹn. Ông ấy đã dạy bà ấy cách đọc kinh Koran, và ông ấy đã mua cho bà ấy một bộ kinh Koran bằng tiếng Ả Rập khi bà ấy mới 10 tuổi.
